RunoffFacts.fact: "Each year 1.2 trillion gallons of untreated sewage, stormwater, and industrial waste are dumped into US water"
"In developing countries, 70 percent of industrial wastes are dumped untreated into waters, polluting the usable water supply."
"Federal authorities estimate that the headwaters of 40 percent of Western rivers are tainted with toxic discharge from abandoned mines"
In the United States there are thought to be over 20,000 known abandoned and uncontrolled hazardous waste sites and these sites contaminate groundwater
"Industry dumps an estimated 300-400 MT of polluted waste in waters every year"
"Nitrate from agriculture is the most common chemical contaminant in the world’s freshwater"
"In the USA there are 12-18 million cases of water-borne diseases a year"
"In the United States, 40% of the rivers and 46% of the lakes are polluted and are considered unhealthy for swimming, fishing or aquatic life"
"Currently, 44% of all wastewater on Earth returns to the environment untreated"
Runoffs can lead to 'dead zones' in water that are deprived of oxygen

LitterFacts.fact: Litter can collect in many areas of fresh water like the surface, water floor, water columns, and inside living things
Most common form of litter found in freshwater is plastic, followed by metal, glass, cloth, footwear, paper, and wood
The majority of waste entering freshwater comes from food packaging
"River deltas receive 52 percent of river-borne plastic pollution, though they make up less than 1 percent of global coastlines"
Waste found on the water surface stays there until it decomposes, washes up on shore, sinks to the water floor, or is removed by other means
Litter is most any waste that is disposed of incorrectly
"The Healthy Land & Water Clean Up Program has recorded a 50% increase in the number of plastic water bottles collected from local waterways"
80% of litter found in waterways is plastic
Most plastic objects that end up in fresh water don't biodegrade
"Cigarettes are the most frequently littered item, with an estimated 9.7 billion cigarette butts discarded along roadways and waterways"
It is estimated that +1,000,000 animals die a year from eating or being trapped in trash
Germs and parasites stick to litter, facilitating the spread of disease, especially for animals that come in contact with it.
Plastic takes 10 to 20 years to decompose
Aluminum cans take 200 to 500 years to decompose
Glass bottles are estimated to take 1 million years to decompose
The average person walks by 12,000 items of litter every day
"Litter decreases oxygen levels in the water when it decays"
"Industry dumps an estimated 300-400 MT of polluted waste in waters every year"

IndustrialWasteFacts.fact: "Industry accounts for 20% of the freshwater withdrawn worldwide. This water is used in production and becomes polluted"
Industrial waste can be caused through burning fossil fuels, releasing chemical solvents, leaking radioactive materials, not treating waste properly, amongst others.
Industrial waste is categorized as 'hazardous' if it can be ignited, is corrosive, toxic, or radioactive.
Industrial waste can lead to eutrophication (water with an abundance of minerals) and can later lead to an excessive amount of algae growth, and then a red tide.
"Around the world, some 2 billion tonnes of human waste are disposed of in water courses every day."
"A major water use is industrial, which occupies 22% worldwide water use."
"In developing countries, 70 percent of industrial wastes are dumped untreated into waters, polluting the usable water supply."
"Industry dumps an estimated 300-400 MT of polluted waste in waters every year."
"Nitrate from agriculture is the most common chemical contaminant in the world’s groundwater aquifers."
"Every day, over 2 million tons of sewage and industrial and agricultural waste are discharged into the world’s water."
"In 1980, Congress passed the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act, commonly known as the Superfund program, to try to clean up widespread contamination."
"Freshwater is used by many industrial facilities to transport waste away from the facility and into rivers, lakes, and oceans."

OilGreaseFacts.fact: Cleaning oil spills can be more difficult in lakes since water is denser and will slightly sink, making it hard to separate the oil from water
OilGreaseFacts.source: NOAA: Office of Response and Restoration

OilGreaseFacts.fact: "Roughly 706 million gallons of oil enter the ocean every year."
The biggest oil spill that occurred in the use was the 2010 water Horizon BP Oil Spill. 210 million gallons of oil were released into the Gulf of Mexico

"[It is estimated that 2010 Horizon BP oil spill] harmed or killed about 82,000 birds of 102 species; about 6,165 sea turtles; as many as 25,900 marine mammals; and a vast (but unknown) number of fish."
"Oil, dispersed oil and dispersants are all toxic to marine and onshore plants like seagrasses, mangroves and wetland vegetation, which provide habitat and food for many species."
An oil spill that releases 7-700 tonnes of oil is considered 'small', otherwize they are categorized as 'large oil spills'
"The average number of spills per year in the 1970s was approximately 79. This decreased by over 90% to 6.3 in the 2010s"
Oil spills in fresh water can reduce phytoplankton and zooplankton  zooplankton by 70%
" Oil in sediments may be very harmful because sediment traps the oil and affects the organisms that live in or feed off the sediments."
"Marsh environments are among the most sensitive freshwater habitat to oil spills due to the minimal water flow"

SewageWasteWaterFacts.fact: "Wastewater treatment facilities process about 34 billion gallons of wastewater per day."
"Every day, 2 million tons of sewage and industrial and agricultural waste are discharged into the world’s wate."
"SSOs are overflows or releases from sanitary sewer systems and are illegal under the Clean Water Act."
The release of sewage into bodies of water introduces more nutrients into the system, leading to more algae and algae blooms.
Over 860 billion gallons of sewage leaks into the environment every year
Untreated sewage can carry diseases such as salmonella, hepatitis, dysentery, cryptosporidium, amongst others
"A study by the CDC and the National Academy of Sciences concluded that most illnesses caused by eating tainted seafood have human sewage as the root cause."
"There are 600,000 miles of sewer pipes across the country and the average age is 33 years"
"Globally, roughly 50% of wastewater is treated at facilities before being released into nearby bodies of water."
Treated wastewater has been shown to still have a negative impact on freshwater and it's ecosystem.
